newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: North Korea reports 800,000 infants malnourished.
newsitem.headline: North Korea reports 800,000 infants malnourished.

text.p: Some 800,000 children under five in North Korea are malnourished -- 37 percent of that age group -- the U.N. Children's Fund (UNICEF) said on Tuesday.
Estimates from the Ministry of Public Health in Pyongyang indicate 10 percent of the 800,000 are severely malnourished, according to the United Nations agency.
Another 65 percent, have a "moderate" level of malnutrition while the rest are in the "intermediate" category.
Given the worsening famine in North Korea UNICEF expects to more than double its appeal of $4.7 million last April to fund food and medical supplies, according to a spokesman.
UNICEF has begun distributing high-energy milk and medical kits which it flew in on July 1. It expected to bring in another plane load next week.
Stalinist North Korea, which has a population of 23 million, was hit by widespread flooding in 1995 and 1996 which devastated cereal crops.
The spokesman said a survey which UNICEF is due to carry out with the World Food Programme will allow it to determine the level of malnutrition across the country.
The survey, due to start by the end of July, is to be completed in six weeks.
Catherine Bertini, executive director of the Rome-based WFP, is due to give a news conference in Geneva on Wednesday on the situation in North Korea.
WFP, the U.N. agency which plans emergency food aid distribution, cautioned after a visit last month that North Korea was within months of running out of food supplies.

But Ole Gronning, the Pyongyang representative of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies, said last month that government food stocks throughout the country were virtually empty.
More than five million North Koreans are near starvation and could die in coming months unless food arrives, he said.
